awd_titl_txt: Conference: A workshop to understand the current needs for advancing living sentinel research
awd_abstract_narration:
The current global pandemic and the risk of future outbreak events has provided a strong motivation to rethink how we monitor and respond to emergent threats. A potential solution is to create sentinel living systems that detect, recognize, actuate, and mitigate emergent biological threats. To create strong stakeholder engagement and define a vision for sentinel systems, a series of activities will be organized that lead to the development of a research roadmap. This roadmap will frame the foundational challenges in detecting and recognizing health and environmental threats in real time and building devices from living and non-living parts that mitigate those threats using synthetic biology. By bringing together researchers from diverse backgrounds and disciplines, including biology, engineering, and materials, this workshop will draw from broad perspectives and expertise ensuring a robust and rigorous discussion that supports the development of a roadmap that advances in the field. 

The goal of the proposed workshop is to bring together leading scholars in synthetic biology, materials science, and electrical engineering to discuss the foundational knowledge that is required to create smart technologies that detect, recognize, actuate, and mitigate emergent biological threats. Specifically, it will accomplish four objectives. First, prior to the workshop, diverse stakeholders will be engaged using a virtual mechanism to introduce the workshop goals and ask participants to share ideas in response to a set of defined questions. This information will be used to refine the agenda and materials for the workshop to ensure that it stimulates robust stakeholder discussions. Second, focused stakeholder engagement will be accomplished using an in-person workshop. This will involve defining a frame for discussions and a series of breakout sessions where smaller groups of participants discuss and provide feedback on specific topic points. Third, to broaden the in-person workshop participation, virtual breakout sessions will be used to allow remote participants to contribute in real time. These groups will contain stakeholders from different disciplines to bring together different perspectives. Finally, using the digital notes developed through the meeting, participants will be asked to develop a roadmap document in an article form that contains the outcome of recommendations, which will be disseminated to the broader community through a publication.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The recent global pandemic and the risk of future outbreak events has provided a strong motivation to rethink how we monitor and respond to emergent threats. A potential solution is to create sentinel systems that detect, recognize, actuate, and mitigate emergent threats. To create strong stakeholder engagement and define a vision for such living systems, a series of activities were organized around a workshop. There were five major objectives with this project. First, the workshop organizers sought to engage the broader community to ensure that they obtained feedback from diverse perspectives. To achieve this, scholars from across the country were invited to provide their feedback on knowledge gaps and opportunities through an online pre-workshop survey which was widely advertised via social media. Second, the organizers sought to stimulate deep stakeholder discussions that went beyond the data and ideas from the survey. To achieve this, they brought together scholars with diverse expertise from different disciplines to build upon data from the survey. Third, the organizers sought to consider innovation in the context of large societal challenges. To achieve this, six scenarios were generated to consider challenges in different environmental settings, current knowledge gaps, and opportunities and needs for future research. Fourth, the organizers sought to support the inclusion of diverse stakeholders. To achieve this, they coordinated the workshop with breakout groups and reporting that brought together scholars in different locations. Finally, the organizers sought to generate and refine a roadmap for innovation. To achieve this, they used the results from the pre-workshop survey and workshop breakout group reporting to generate recommendations. A workshop report was ultimately generated using the information gleaned from these activities, which has been posted online (doi, 10.25611/3fd7-pz22) so that the community can access this information.
